Band of the Week: Squeeze

14/03/2011

Resident sound-nerd <em>Tom Killingbeck</em> thumbs through reams of musty vinyl so you don't have to. Here are his weekly recommendations...

Image by

By James Bithell

#19: Squeeze Who: Chris Difford, Jools Holland, Harry Kakoulli, Gilson Lavis, Glenn Tilbrook. When: 1970's-Present. Where: UK. Why: After a little run of heavy-as-hell musicians here at Band of the Week, let's relax and gather ourselves with some quintessential English pop. BBC keyboard-bothering gimp Jools Holland wasn't always so uncool, you know. I mean, his first recorded session was with punk rock transsexual Wayne County's band The Electric Chairs in 1976. By then he had already joined new wave upstarts Squeeze, a band formed by songwriting partnership Glenn Tilbrook and Chris Difford, and named after an abortive late Velvet Underground album that featured neither Lou Reed or John Cale. Cale would feature in the Squeeze story, however; as he (for the most part) produced their debut album. Although Cale had been on a run of production jobs which had led to some of the greatest records of the 70s (The Stooges' debut, Nico's The Marble Index, Patti Smith's Horses) his contributions to Squeeze's output were dubious. Firstly, he wanted to call their debut Gay Guys (despite all of the band being straight), and secondly he attempted to coax the band into experimenting and detracting from their obvious succinct pop talents. It was telling that the two hit singles from the record were the only ones produced by the band themselves. Second album Cool For Cats found the band landing on all fours, with a winning clutch of songs that defined their charming low-budget new wave sound. The album's biggest hit, 'Up The Junction', was Squeeze at their most amiable, with its stream of consciousness romantic history spilling out in a stunningly candid and down to earth sort of way. It was an English kitchen-sink cousin of Springsteen's 'The River', lyrics by turn hilarious, cringeworthy, and moving; a strangely intimate torrent of colloquial bittersweet pop. Its other notable single, the title track, is a fairly dated mockney slice of London grit, which pre-empts Kate Nash's cod-cockney posturing by twenty five odd years. It's replete with rhyming slang and innuendo, and definitely a result of the band's endless pub tours in the mid-70s. Their position on Top of the Pops and as the acceptable face of British punk-derived music assured, the band then went on to cut their finest LP, 1980's Argybargy. With their influences stemming from the great tradition of rock & roll and rhythm & blues - Beatles and Kinks as much as the canon of Motown - the band's vision matured on their sophomore effort. Single 'Another Nail In My Heart' is still, arguably, the band's finest moment, a slice of deft, defeated, heartbroken pop that sits with The Cure's 'Pictures of You' and 'There Is A Light That Never Goes Out' by The Smiths as one of the most beautifully sad English romantic moments of the 1980's. The LP overall is still memorable for mixing colourful pop and uniquely sardonic lyrics in a curiously affecting way. The band would split and reunite several times in their career, and although there would be great moments to come - 'Last Time Forever' and 'Tempted' for example - they'd sadly never recapture the matey familiarity of those two records again; although Mr Holland would of course end up with an OBE and a rather successful TV career. Influences: Bob Dylan, The Beatles, The Kinks, Jimi Hendrix, Ray Charles. Influenced: Blur, The Boo Radleys, Pulp, Ben Folds Five, Head Automatica. Sample Lyric: 'The devil came and took me / From bar to street to bookie'. Which Record: Argybargy (A&M, 1980)
